tips.Still in a relationship: Keep this plan updated, and remember you can always reach out if things escalate.
tips.Planning to leave: Start packing small items now so you’re ready when you decide to leave.
tips.Post-separation: It’s normal to feel unsettled, refer back to this plan whenever you need a safety reminder.

warmup2.question: What city do you live in?

tips.template: Save the local support numbers for {city} in your phone's speed-dial so you can call immediately if you need help.

warmup3.question: Which room in your home feels the safest if you need to get away quickly?

tips.template: Keep your essentials (phone, keys, and a small flashlight) in {safe_room} so you can grab them instantly when you need to leave.

tips.Family: Let those you live with: Family, know your safe room and cue-word so they can support you in an emergency.
tips.Roommates: Let those you live with: Roommates, know your safe room and cue-word so they can support you in an emergency.
tips.Alone: Since you live alone, identify a trusted neighbor or friend and share your safe room location with them.
tips.Partner: Because you live with your partner, keep your safety plan hidden (in {safe_room}), and consider storing a digital copy in a password-protected note so they won't see.

tips.No: Even without children, it helps to identify a second safe space in your home.

tips.template:
Practice your safety plan with your children so that when they hear {code_word},
they know exactly what to do.

branch2.question: Which form(s) of abuse are you experiencing?

tips.template: If you face {abuse_types} abuse, remember you don't have to face it alone. Reach out to your emergency contact right away.

branch3.question: Are you recording the incidents (dates, times, details?

tips.Yes: Log each incident (date, time, and a brief note) so you have clear records if needed later.
tips.No: Even brief notes on your phone can be helpful. Start logging today.
